ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the international Surrealist avant-garde through its artworks, literature, and experiments. We looked at the Surrealist movement both in France and overseas, spanning the early to mid-twentieth century and even into present day. In addition to all the analytical and writing skills of art history classes, this class incorporated practicums that supplemented the readings and discussions each week.
I learned how to reconsider how I study and ways to experience knowledge. I learned about Surrealism and its political and artistic history.
Writing, critical thinking, and being more introspective/meditative with the ideas gone over in class.

I gleaned a much more comprehensive and nuanced understanding of the Surrealism movement, its philosophical tenets, the evolution of its aesthetic/socio-political principles and members, as well as surrealist modes of thinking about the world that could be applied outside of class context. I also learned how to better analyze and understand Surrealist art.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is really well organized: chronologically, geographically, thematically. We trace the movement of Surrealism from Paris outward into the French colonies, and all throughout, the discussions are framed by certain polarities that the Surrealists addressed in their work.

Strengths: The weekly practicums were really engaging and helped me engage with the course materials in a really non-traditional, non-academic and exciting way. I like that there was an organized polarity that we studied each week and that the class had a good mixture of lecture and discussion. The professor was great and was super engaged and passionate about the course material.
Weaknesses: The readings were so heavy, theoretical, and often nonsensical that trying to read through them each week was very stressful. Since they were so difficult, I found that it took me an extraordinary amount of time each week just to get through many of them, and then in class we might end up spending only about ten minutes on it. For those that I tried to skim when I was short on time, I often ended up more confused and taking away very little than before I had started. I wish we could have slowed down and dived really deep into some of the dense, theoretical texts or read secondary literature that could have helped us break it down on our own time.
More notes or basic guidelines on how to interact with the readings in class would be very helpful! Some of the readings were a bit dense / difficult to digest

Strengths: The readings were both interesting and challenging. The organization of the canvas discussions plus the in-class coverage of these readings was extremely well done - the class discussions were generative, exciting, and deeply engaging because they were bolstered by the personal practicums (in accordance with that week's theme) we engaged in and posted to canvas. There was so much interesting content that we sometimes couldn't get to all of it, so if the seminar could be longer (although that might be mentally taxing) or meet more frequently that would allow more room for discussions.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We used Canvas discussions both for weekly practicums and for a completely asynchronous makeup class, and I think both worked really well; I liked that the practicums continued to be available online throughout the semester.
Practicums were hugely beneficial to my experience

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Engaging professor and fascinating material.
Yes! This is such an informative, engaging, and fun course; there will be something in this class that captivates you, no matter your interests or prior familiarity with Surrealism.

Yes, I would recommend the course to others, since I learned a lot from it and definitely understand the Surrealism movement a lot better. One thing I will say is that the class focuses a LOT on the political and theoretical side of Surrealism (the Surrealist manifestos, organization of pessimism, etc) and a lot less than I expected on Surrealist artwork itself.
100% ! One of the best classes I've taken, would be better in person.

I would highly recommend this course for any student interested in surrealism but also for anyone looking for a challenging art history course. THe contents of the course are refreshing, illuminating (about the ways one views the world), cerebral yet intuitive as well. Professor Fiduccia is an incredible professor to work with - kind, brilliant, thoughtful, and passionate about the course and about all her students' insights and ideas.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Practicums take-home experiments to help us better understand the concepts covered in class.
